sen.j: 虚無僧（こむそう）とは禅宗の一派である普化宗の僧であり、剃髪しない半僧半俗の存在である。
sen.e: Komuso is a Buddhist monk of Fuke sect from a type of Zen sect who did not shave their hair and lived as half monk and half as ordinary people.
Komuso is a Buddhist monk of the Fuke sect who do not shave their heads and live as half monk and half ordinary person.
Komuso were monks of the Fuke sect of Zen Buddhism who did not shave their heads in the traditional monk fashion and, co-existed as monks in the day to day lay world.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 普化宗は中国（唐）の普化を祖とし、日本には臨済宗の僧・心地覚心が中国に渡り、普化の法系の張参に竹管吹簫の奥義を受け、張参の弟子「宝伏」ら4人の居士を伴い、1254年（建長6年）に帰国し紀伊由良の興国寺に普化庵を設けて住まわせたことに始まる。
sen.e: The Fuke sect originated from Fuke of China (Tung), in Japan it started when monk of Rinzai Sect of Buddhism, Kakushin SHINCHI went to China and had a favor from San CHO, who was Buddhist law of Fuke sect of 竹管吹簫, he took four Kyoshi (Buddhist layman) of San CHO's discipline such as 'Hofuku', he then went back to Japan and established Fukean of Kokoku-ji Temple which belonged to Yura KI, let them live in the temple.
sen.cmt: 竹管吹簫, 宝伏 読み方→定訳不明
sen.e: The Fuke sect originated from Fuke of China (Tung), in Japan it started when monk of Rinzai Sect of Buddhism, Kakushin SHINCHI went to China and received favor from San CHO, Buddhist law of the Fuke sect of 竹管吹簫, he took four Kyoshi (Buddhist layman) San CHO disciples such as 'Hofuku', and then returned to Japan and established Fukean of Kokoku-ji Temple which belonged to Yura KI, and let them live in the temple.

sen.j: 「古くは、『こもそう（薦僧）』ということが多く、もと坐臥用のこもを腰に巻いていたところからという。」
sen.e: In old days they were often called "Komoso" which the name was originated from the monk wearing Komo around their hip while they meditate and sleep.'

sen.j: 虚無僧の様相については、「尺八を吹き喜捨を請いながら諸国を行脚修行した有髪の僧」とされている。
sen.e: It was said the way how the Komuso looked like was,they used to play Shakuhachi bamboo flute and they did not shave their head, they traveled to go on a pilgrimage all over Japan and gave alms.
Komuso used to play Shakuhachi bamboo flutes and they did not shave their heads, they traveled on pilgrimages all over Japan and gave alms.
A Komuso was considered to be an itinerant priest who 'traveled around the provinces while collecting alms by playing the Shakuhachi (bamboo flute) and, did not have a shaved head.'
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーションなどを変えました。

sen.j: また、「多く小袖に袈裟を掛け、深編笠をかぶり刀を帯した。」とされる。
sen.e: they often put kesa (Buddhist stole) on sleeves and wore braided bamboo hat and carried a sword.'

sen.j: はじめは普通の編笠をかぶり、白衣を着ていた。
sen.e: Initially they wore an ordinary bamboo hat with white costume, but they were stated as follows by the the Tokugawa shogunate after the Edo period.
Initially they wore an ordinary bamboo hat with a white robe, but they were described as follows by the Tokugawa shogunate after the Edo period.
Initially Komuso wore an ordinary bamboo hat and were draped in a white robe.

sen.j: 托鉢の際には藍色または鼠色の無紋の服に、男帯をまえに結び、腰に袋にいれた予備の尺八をつける。
sen.e: They were to wear navy or gray clothes with no pattern with otoko-obi (a sash (an obi) for men's use) in the front, they also put spare Shakuhachi bamboo flute in the bag tied around the hip.
They were to wear navy blue or gray clothes with no pattern with otoko-obi (a sash - an obi, for men) in the front, they also put a spare Shakuhachi bamboo flute in a bag tied around the hip.

sen.j: 足には5枚重ねの草履を履き、手に尺八を持つ。
sen.e: They wore five layers of zori (Japanese footwear sandals), and carried Shakuhachi in their hands.

sen.j: 1614年（慶長19年）の虚無僧掟書により武者修行の宗門と心得て全国を自由に往来することが徳川家康により許されたと主張している。
sen.e: According to Komuso Okitegaki (a law for komuso (begging Zen priest of the Fuke sect)) issued in 1614, it insisted Komuso were allowed to travel over Japan without any permission by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA since they were considered as traveling fencers of doctrine, however later it was found out that the Kmuso Okitegaki was false documents.

According to Komuso Okitegaki (a rule for komuso - begging Zen priest of the Fuke sect) issued in 1614, it insisted Komuso were allowed to travel all over Japan without any permission from Ieyasu TOKUGAWA since they were considered as traveling fencers of doctrine, however, later it was found out that the Kmuso Okitegaki were false documents.

According to a 1614 feudal law (okitegaki) pertaining to Komuso itinerant priests that was approved and advocated by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, the Komuso were permitted to travel around Japan as part of their sect's martial training and to gain knowledge.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。

sen.j: 罪を犯した武士が普化宗の僧となれば、刑をまぬがれ保護された。
sen.e: Since the Samurai who committed a crime could get away from the punishment and were protected by becoming a monk of Fuke sect, there were many Samurai who indulged in debauchery and doing nothing but to wonder around after the middle of the Edo period, the bakufu started setting regulations against them.

Since Samurai who committed crime could get away without punishment and were protected by becoming a monk of the Fuke sect, there were many Samurai who indulged in debauchery and did nothing but to wonder around after the middle of the Edo period, the bakufu started setting regulations against them.
If samurai who committed crimes became monks of the Fuke sect of Buddhism, they escaped punishment and were protected.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。

sen.j: このことから、江戸時代中期以降には、遊蕩無頼の徒が虚無僧姿になって横行するようになり、幕府は虚無僧を規制するようになった。
sen.e: As a result, from the middle of the Edo period onwards, gangs of louts living the high-life whilst posing as Komuso became rampant so, the shogunate placed restrictions on the Komuso.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。

sen.j: 1871年（明治4年）、明治政府は幕府との関係が深い普化宗を廃止する太政官布告を出した。
sen.e: In 1871 the Meiji Government issued edict of Dajokan (Grand Council of state) to abolish Fuke sect which had strong relationship with the bakufu, due to this, Komuso were not qualified as monk any longer and their family registration were incorporated as ordinary people.

In 1871 the Meiji Government issued the edict of Dajokan (Grand Council of state) to abolish the Fuke sect which had a strong relationship with the bakufu, due to this, Komuso were not qualified as monks any longer and their family registrations were changed to that of ordinary people.
In 1871, the Department of State of the Meiji administration issued ordinances which abolished the Fuke Sect which had been a close cohort of the Shogunate.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。

sen.j: 虚無僧は僧侶の資格を失い、民籍に編入された。
sen.e: The Komuso lost their right to be priests and, they were incorporated into family registers.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。

sen.j: 1888年（明治21年）に京都東福寺の塔頭の一つ善慧院を明暗寺として明暗協会が設立されて虚無僧行脚が復活した。
sen.e: In 1888 Zennein, one of the minor temple in the Kyoto Tofuku-ji Temple site was decided as Meian-ji Temple, and Meian kyokai (明暗協会) was establied to start pilgrimage of Komuso.
